success_criteria: input element or button is missing an associated label, it contains an alt attribute, or its label is empty

error_fixes.problem_type: input element or button is missing an associated label, it contains an alt attribute, or its label is empty
error_fixes.fixed_line: <label for="name">Name:</label><input type="text" id="name" name="name" placeholder="Your name">
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Look for `input` elements and `button` elements on the page.
2. Check if each `input` element has a corresponding `label` element associated with it.
3. Check if each `input` element has a valid `alt` attribute (if it's an image input).
4. Check if each `button` element has text content or an associated `label` element.
5. Identify any missing labels or empty labels that need to be fixed for accessibility purposes.

success_criteria: Audio or video element should avoid automatically playing audio
fixed_example:
<video controls>
<source src="bookstore-video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

error_fixes.problem_type: Audio or video element should avoid automatically playing audio
error_fixes.fixed_line: <video id="video" controls><source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">Your browser does not support the video tag.</video>
error_fixes.CoT:
To find the issue related to automatically playing audio or video, we need to look for any `<video>` or `<audio>` elements in the HTML code and check if they have attributes that would cause them to autoplay. We should also check any `<script>` elements that may have functions triggering the audio or video to play automatically.

Let's review the HTML code and identify any `<video>` or `<audio>` elements that might be set to autoplay or have autoplay functionality in scripts.

success_criteria: <b> <i> or <font> tag should not be used

error_fixes.problem_type: <b>, <i>, or <font> tag should not be used
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Look through the HTML code for any instances of `<b>`, `<i>`, or `<font>` tags.
2. Determine if any of these tags are used for styling purposes.
3. If any of these tags are found and used for styling, consider replacing them with appropriate CSS styles.
4. Make sure the content is still accessible and understandable without relying on these tags for formatting.

success_criteria: onmousedown event missing onkeydown event or script is not keyboard accessible

error_fixes.problem_type: onmousedown event missing onkeydown event or script is not keyboard accessible
error_fixes.CoT:
To find the accessability issue related to the `onmousedown` event missing `onkeydown` event or script not being keyboard accessible, we need to:

1. Look for any elements that have `onmousedown` event attributes.
2. Make sure that those elements also have `onkeydown` event attributes.
3. Ensure that the functionality triggered by these events is accessible via the keyboard.

Let's start by examining the `button` elements with `onmousedown` events.

success_criteria: meta refresh with a time-out is used.

error_fixes.CoT: To find the empty `title` element, we need to inspect the `title` element in the HTML document. The `title` element should contain a descriptive and informative title for the webpage. An empty `title` element can cause issues for users who rely on screen readers or search engines to understand the content of the page. We need to make sure that the `title` element is filled with relevant information.

To identify the issue of the anchor element containing no text, I would need to examine each `<a>` tag within the HTML and ensure that each one has meaningful text content. Specifically, I would check if the anchor elements have text content inside them that provides a clear and concise description of the link's purpose.

success_criteria: document language not identified or incorrect

error_fixes.problem_type: document language not identified or incorrect
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Ensure that the "lang" attribute in the opening `<html>` tag is correctly set to identify the language of the document. You can check if it is set to "en" for English.
  
2. Double-check that the language attribute is spelled correctly and is using the appropriate ISO language code.

Let me know if you find the issue.

success_criteria: input element has more than one associated label

error_fixes.problem_type: input element has more than one associated label
error_fixes.fixed_line: <label for="email">Email:</label><input type="email" id="email" name="email" placeholder="Your email">
error_fixes.CoT:
- Identify all the input elements in the form.
- Check for associated labels for each input element.
- Confirm if any input element has more than one associated label.

success_criteria: element does not have complete start and end tags or id attribute is not unique

error_fixes.problem_type: Element does not have complete start and end tags
error_fixes.fixed_line: <label for="email">Email:</label><input type="email" id="email" name="email" placeholder="Your email">
error_fixes.CoT: Sure! Let's start by looking for incomplete start and end tags in the HTML code. We need to ensure that all elements have complete opening and closing tags. Let's also make sure that all id attributes are unique. Let's begin reviewing the code.
